key_dates.description: First turning point date of February 2026. Potential change in price direction (+/- 1 trading day).
Second turning point date. Potential reversal or continuation signal (+/- 1 trading day).

Third turning point date. Aligns with the central weekly cycle of the month and the daily cycle. This is considered the strongest and most significant turning point. Also marks the center of the concentrated risk window (Feb 17-20).
Fourth turning point date. Aligns with a daily central point around Feb 27. Also expected to be an important turning point as the weekly cycle of that week aligns with a key daily cycle.

seasonal: February is considered a slightly negative month for the S&P500 based on seasonality. Over the last 30 years, multi-season statistics show: Feb 3 has ~68% probability of a rise, Feb 10 has ~68% probability of a rise, and Feb 11 has ~71% probability of a rise. Three out of four decade-level patterns point upward and one pattern closed with a decline. No active monthly cycle is present this month. Overall seasonal bias is mildly negative with a slight upward tilt in the first half.

statistics.detail: Approximately 68% probability of upward movement based on 30-year seasonal data.
Approximately 68% probability of upward movement based on 30-year seasonal data.
Approximately 71% probability of upward movement based on 30-year seasonal data.
Over the last 30 years, the index closed higher on Feb 16 compared to Feb 6 in approximately 80% of cases (24 out of 30 times).
Key cyclical convergence zone. Weekly cycle ending around Feb 20 is considered the strongest of the month. Multiple cycles converge here making it a high-probability turning point.
Weekly cycle ending around Feb 27 also aligns with a significant daily cycle turning point. Expected to be a notable turning point.

insights: February 2026 is a month where time is compressed and markets lose patience. There are months where the market gives comfortable margins, but February feels different.

The risk concentration window is February 17-20. This is the central and most cycle-dense window of the month. When multiple cycles converge in one zone, the market tends to react quickly and powerfully - sometimes prematurely. Risk in this window is bidirectional (can move sharply up or down).

A 'continuing cycle/date' means the turning point date serves as a default entry rather than a reversal. If price arrives at the turning point moving upward, in 75% of historical cases the move continued in that direction until the next turning point.

A 'double cycle' occurs when two turning point dates appear near the same date (e.g., Feb 22). The first date typically causes a direction change, but the second date may restore the original trend direction.

Eight months of consecutive S&P500 gains is accumulating like a spring. The D9 indicator is lit at level 8, an extreme level. The monthly chart shows an additional signal historically appearing when the market is due for a correction phase.

CNN Fear & Greed Index stands at 58 (end of January). When the index shows 'greed', look for when markets lean toward fear - this is often where the real opportunity lies. End of January: 24 weeks / End of December: 46 weeks / End of January: 57 weeks.

In the last 3 months, the minor trend shifted from a clear uptrend to sideways chop with a slight upward bias. Previously, all three trends (primary, secondary, minor) were aligned upward - now the possibility exists to trade both directions.

The daily chart shows buyer strength is weakening. It still shows buyer presence but with clear signs of fatigue - a bearish divergence (sticky cap) pattern marked in red on the attached chart shows buyers are failing to break highs convincingly.
Futures contracts: Never risk more than 1% per trade during the month. In oil/crude: no games - do not leave open positions over the weekend.
For other assets (S&P, gold, euro dollar, Bitcoin): mandatory stop-loss within the system, and only proper position sizing at week's end.
Stocks: Preserve ammunition and do not remain without cash reserves. Stay with liquidity of 30% of portfolio. Keep cash available to capitalize on dips instead of absorbing them fully.
2026 is marked as a panic year in the annual report. There will be a shock event, exactly like those seen during COVID or similar periods where the narrative changed in one day.

Iran 45-year cycle connecting to January 2026: The cyclical connection from the 1981 American hostage release and Reagan inauguration repeats. Every 45-year jump brings another turning point in Iran-West relations. February 2026 appears as one of the most critical time windows from a geopolitical perspective.

Russia adds another layer - a potential large financial trigger. The window also affects Russia. There is expectation of rapid developments, possibly a financial scandal, unexpected bank collapse, or similar trigger igniting a sharp market reaction.

Japan 36-year cycle: Japanese equity indices peaked meaningfully on December 29, 1989 before an 80% crash. Today the Japanese index is again at all-time highs, and we are at the beginning of the 36-year cycle window, placing the Japanese market in a potentially sensitive zone of instability.

The weekly chart primary trend is still bullish but time is starting to press. From a wide angle, the weekly chart still looks positive. The primary trend continues upward, so every decline at this stage is first considered a technical correction within a longer healthy trend. But a quiet warning light is forming - not because the trend is broken, but because the quality of the advance is weakening.

In January we received volatility within a range of about 3%, with rises and falls in rotation including a breakout to highs and a close. In parallel, a pattern emerged that quantifies risk: the rises came at known trading cycle turning points, and the declines came at higher trading cycle turning points.
Principle: Work with an open mind, not with a racing heartbeat. The key is not to fear corrections, nor to blindly support the rally.

technical.indicators: Small negative divergence present in both RSI and MACD. During the last wave of gains from mid-November through end of December, the MACD curve remained below the action line - a signal of weakness within a rising trend. This pattern also appeared in January-February 2025 before a strong correction wave. D9 indicator lit at level 8 (extreme). The 50-day moving average and 100-day moving average are visible on the daily chart as dynamic support zones. The Fibonacci 38.2% retracement of the rally from April sits at approximately 6,175 points. A return to the retest zone reflects a decline of roughly 11.5-13% from the index highs. In leveraged instruments (3x ETFs), this translates to approximately 35% decline. A confirmed break below 6,536 would be the first sign of transitioning from a shallow correction to a deeper one that could also impact the weekly chart.

summary: February 2026 is a compressed, cycle-dense month for the S&P500 with four key turning points on Feb 4, 13, 20, and 27. After eight consecutive months of gains, the index is showing signs of exhaustion with weakening buyer strength and negative divergences on RSI and MACD, while the primary weekly trend remains bullish. The critical risk window of Feb 17-20 features multiple converging cycles and geopolitical catalysts (Iran 45-year cycle, Russia financial trigger risk, Japan 36-year cycle), making it a period requiring heightened caution, reduced position sizes, mandatory stop-losses, and at least 30% cash reserves.
risk_notes: 2026 is designated as a 'panic year' in the annual report - expect a shock event similar to COVID-era market disruptions where the story changes in a single day.
The Feb 17-20 risk window is bidirectional - sharp moves can occur in either direction. Do not assume direction, let price confirm first.
Eight months of consecutive gains creates spring-like tension. D9 indicator at level 8 is an extreme reading historically associated with correction phases.
Iran 45-year geopolitical cycle peaks in January-February 2026, with internal unrest (nationwide protests, inflation, currency collapse). This could trigger rapid market-moving developments.
Russia layer: potential for financial scandal, unexpected large bank collapse, or similar trigger that could shock markets during this window.
Japan 36-year cycle: Japanese markets at all-time highs entering the cycle window that began with the 1989 crash. Instability risk is elevated.
MACD remaining below the action line during the recent rally is a weakness signal that preceded the January-February 2025 correction.
Caution is not a recommendation - it is a requirement. Moves this month can be large, volatility high, and rate of change can increase suddenly.

If leveraged (3x ETFs or futures): reduce to half position size and ensure no leverage going into weekends. A gap against your position from a military event or other shock could devastate the account.
Do not chase price moves in compressed time windows. Chasing price action in a dense cycle zone is a recipe for mistakes.
In crude oil: absolutely no open positions over the weekend. Oil is the asset most likely to surprise precisely when you feel confident it will not move.
CNN Fear & Greed at 58 suggests markets are in a blow-off environment where sentiment and FOMO drive decisions rather than data. Forecasts break down in such environments.
A 10-15% correction does not negate a positive trend - it restores balance and reduces accumulated risk when the price rises too fast without pause.
